author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
review: Set in the fictional town of Maycomb, Alabama during the 1930s, the novel explores the themes of racial injustice and moral growth through the eyes of young Scout Finch, whose father, Atticus Finch, defends a black man falsely accused of raping a white woman.

author: Harper Lee
review: Set in a totalitarian society where the government, led by the Party and its enigmatic leader Big Brother, exercises complete control over all aspects of life, 1984 follows the story of Winston Smith as he rebels against the oppressive regime and struggles for freedom of thought and expression.

author: George Orwell
review: Set in the summer of 1922 on Long Island and in New York City, the novel depicts the glamorous but ultimately tragic lives of Jay Gatsby, a wealthy and mysterious socialite, and his obsession with Daisy Buchanan, a married woman from his past.

author: J.D. Salinger
review: A poignant exploration of adolescence.Set in early 19th-century England, the novel follows the romantic exploits of the Bennet sisters, particularly Elizabeth Bennet, as they navigate the societal norms, class distinctions, and misunderstandings of love and marriage.

author: Jane Austen
review: Narrated by the disillusioned teenager Holden Caulfield, the novel recounts his experiences in New York City after being expelled from his prep school. As he grapples with issues of identity, alienation, and the phoniness of adult society, Holden searches for authenticity and connection.

bookName: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone
author: J.K. Rowling
review: A pioneering work of modernist fiction, To the Lighthouse explores the complexities of human relationships, the passage of time, and the search for meaning and understanding. Set on the Isle of Skye, the novel delves into the thoughts and emotions of the Ramsay family and their guests as they grapple with personal and existential dilemmas.

author: J.R.R. Tolkien
review: Spanning several generations of the Buend√≠a family in the fictional town of Macondo, the novel blends myth, history, and fantasy to chronicle the rise and fall of the family and the town itself. Through its rich tapestry of characters and events, One Hundred Years of Solitude explores themes of love, power, and the cyclical nature of time.

author: J.R.R. Tolkien
review: Regarded as one of the greatest American novels, Moby-Dick follows the voyage of the whaling ship Pequod, commanded by the obsessive Captain Ahab, as it pursues the elusive white whale Moby Dick. Interwoven with philosophical musings, vivid descriptions of whaling life, and themes of obsession and fate, the novel is both an epic adventure and a profound exploration of the human condition.
